brief_description: During the human B cell (Bc) recall response, rapid cell division results in multiple Bc subpopulations. RNA microarray and functional analyses showed that proliferating CD27lo cells are a transient pre-plasmablast population, expressing genes associated with Bc receptor editing. Undivided cells had an active transcriptional program of non-ASC B cell functions, including cytokine secretion and costimulation, suggesting a link between innate and adaptive Bc responses.  Transcriptome analysis suggested a gene regulatory network for CD27lo and CD27hi Bc differentiation.
brief_title: Characterization of in vitro Stimulated B Cells from Human Subjects
condition_studied: Subpopulations of CpG-activated memory B cells

endpoints: Statistically significant changes in mRNA expression of key molecules between subpopulations by microarray. Quantitative RT-PCR confirmation of changes in selected mRNA levels. Consistent changes in protein levels of specific proteins of interest. Phenotypic confirmation of continued differentiation of CD27lo cells after sorting and re-culture by multi-parameter flow cytometry.
hypothesis: Proliferating CD27lo memory B cells serve alternative functions to immunoglobulin secretion. An alternative hypothesis was supported by the data; CD27lo cells are a transient pre-plasmablast population.
objectives: To characterize a novel population of human CD27lo memory B cells after in vitro stimulation
